newsitem.title: USA: 'Mad cow' crisis clouds biotech crops - EU attache.
newsitem.headline: 'Mad cow' crisis clouds biotech crops - EU attache.

text.p: This year's "mad cow" crisis, by shaking consumer confidence in Europe, has cast shadows on biotech crops, the European Union's agricultural counselor in Washington said Tuesday.

While the EU has approved sale of an herbicide-tolerant soybean, action has lagged on a U.S.-developed biotech corn plant. Some environmental groups want both crops barred from Europe. Other groups want the crops to carry special labels.
"The essense of the argument is the same," EU ag counselor Tassos Haniotis said -- that skepticism was proper until thorough proof of the safety of the products.

"They (consumers) insist on getting answers that are convincing," he told a conference sponsored by the U.S. Agriculture Department. As a result, he said, regulators have to consider consumer concerns as well as scientific issues.

Beef consumption plummeted in Europe this year after researchers suggested a possible link between "mad cow" disease, bovine spongiform encephalopothy, and a similar disease in humans. A few years earlier, British officials discounted any danger.
The crisis, Haniotis said, set the "tone for consumer behavior in Europe that extends beyond" beef to biotech.
During his speech, Haniotis said it would be 2002 before any Eastern and Central European nations joined the EU. Ten nations have applied for membership.
Accession would include long transition periods and would not require all new members to progress at the same rate.
Some speakers at the conference said EU expansion would drive up farm subsidy costs sharply unless EU supports were reformed. Haniotis said the cost would be lower than thought.
All the same, he said the EU was considering reforms to avoid a return to surplus output. Reform would aim at greater competitiveness, he said.
